metadata.title: Development of inhalable curcumin loaded Nano-in-Microparticles for bronchoscopic photodynamic therapy

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
European Journal of Pharmaceutical Sciences
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/ejps
Development of inhalable curcumin loaded Nano-in-Microparticles for bronchoscopic photodynamic therapy Elias Baghdana, Lili Dusea, Julia Janina Schüera, Shashank Reddy Pinnapireddya, Marcel Pourasgharb, Jens Schäfera, Marc Schneiderb, Udo Bakowskya,⁎
a Department of Pharmaceutics and Biopharmaceutics, University of Marburg, Robert-Koch-Str. 4, 35037 Marburg, Germany bDepartment of Pharmacy, Biopharmaceutics and Pharmaceutical Technology, Saarland University, Campus C4 1, 66123 Saarbrücken, Germany
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Nanoparticles Curcumin Photodynamic therapy Pulmonary drug delivery Spray drying Cancer
A B S T R A C T
Photodynamic therapy is amongst the most rapidly developing therapeutic strategies against cancer. However, most photosensitizers are administered intravenously with very few reports about pulmonary applications. To address this issue, an inhalable formulation consisting of nanoparticles loaded with photosensitizer (i.e. curcumin) was developed. The nanoparticles were prepared using nanoprecipitation method. Dynamic light scattering measurements of the curcumin loaded nanoparticles revealed a hydrodynamic diameter of 181.20 ± 11.52 nm. In vitro irradiation experiments with human lung epithelial carcinoma cells (A549) showed a selective cellular toxicity of the nanoparticles upon activation using LED irradiating device. Moreover, curcumin nanoparticles exhibited a dose-dependent photocytotoxicity and the IC50 values of curcumin were directly dependent on the radiation fluence used. The nanoparticles were subsequently spray dried using mannitol as a stabilizer to produce Nano-in-Microparticles with appropriate aerodynamic properties for a sufficient deposition in the lungs. This was confirmed using the next generation impactor, which revealed a large fine particle fraction (64.94 ± 3.47%) and a mass median aerodynamic diameter of 3.02 ± 0.07 μm. Nano-in-Microparticles exhibited a good redispersibility and disintegrated into the original nanoparticles upon redispersion in aqueous medium. The Langmuir monolayer experiments revealed an excellent compatibility of the nanoparticles with the lung surfactant. Results from this study showed that the Nano-in-Microparticles are promising drug carriers for the photodynamic therapy of lung cancer.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
According to the world health organization (WHO), lung cancer is a leading cause of death globally. Despite the improvements in survival rates shown by traditional treatments like surgery, chemotherapy or radiotherapy (Johnson et al., 2014), the search for a more effective yet patient-friendly therapy continues. Recently, photodynamic therapy (PDT) has emerged as an evolving therapeutic strategy against cancer.
With its high safety profile and minimally invasive nature, PDT offers several advantages over conventional treatments, which are normally associated with systemic toxicity and undesirable side effects (Brown et al., 2004; Juarranz et al., 2008). Bronchoscopic PDT is one of the methods used in the endoluminal treatment of lung cancer. It involves the administration of a photoactive substance (i.e. photosensitizer) followed by illumination of the tumor mass with light of a specific wavelength using a flexible fiberoptic bronchoscope. However, many photosensitizers suffer from limitations and drawbacks related to off-target toxicity, low water solubility or poor bioavailability. Therefore, researchers have focused on developing more efficient and selective nanoformulations with controlled release properties (Paszko et al., 2011; Mahmoud et al., 2015; Mahmoud et al., 2017). Furthermore, a suitable route of administration must be chosen, so that the photosensitizer reaches its target tissue and accumulates in therapeutic concentrations. Although PDT has been effectively employed to treat several types of lung cancer (Moghissi, 2004), intravenous administration is still the route of choice for most of the clinically approved photosensitizers with only a few reports of pulmonary drug delivery (van Straten et al., 2017).
Consequently, an opportunity exists to use photosensitizer loaded nanoformulations exploiting the numerous advantages of lung delivery such as: being non-invasive route of administration, a lower administered dose and minimum systemic exposure of drug intended for local application (Liang et al., 2015). These nanoformulations, however, must have specific physicochemical properties (e.g. appropriate aerodynamic particle size) to overcome the biological barriers of the lung (Chow et al., 2007; Patton et al., 2010). Various strategies have been developed to transform nanocarriers into inhalable formulations that can be administered using dry powder inhalers, metered-dose inhalers, or nebulizers (Yang et al., 2008; Zhang et al., 2011).
In the last decade, Nano-in-Microparticles (NiMps) emerged as an interesting drug carrier with superior aerodynamic properties and a higher deposition in the lungs. NiMps are microparticles consisting of two main components: nanoparticles and an excipient (e.g. mannitol or trehalose) serving as a wall material to embed the nanoparticles and stabilize them during the atomization process used to produce a more stable dry powder form (Bohr et al., 2014; Wang et al., 2017). Spray drying is still the main preparation method of NiMps for many reasons: being a single-step technique with variable process parameters and suitable for thermolabile substances especially proteins and polymers with low glass transition temperatures (Vehring, 2008; Baghdan et al., 2018). Several studies have reported the feasibility of preparing NiMps by spray drying nanoparticles to produce a dry powder for inhalation and preserve the physicochemical characteristics of the original nanoparticles (Grenha et al., 2007; Lebhardt et al., 2011; Tewes et al., 2014; Torge et al., 2017).
The aim of this work was to develop a photosensitizer loaded formulation in the form of a dry powder for inhalation. This, together with bronchoscopic PDT would offer an effective treatment against lung cancer. Curcumin was chosen as naturally occurring photosensitizer with diverse applications in the field of PDT (Zorofchian Moghadamtousi et al., 2014). To increase its selectivity and expand its range of application, curcumin has been encapsulated within nanoformulations (e.g. liposomes or nanoparticles) (Pinnapireddy et al., 2017; Duse et al., 2018a; Duse et al., 2018b). In this study, curcumin loaded nanoparticles were prepared and subjected to several characterizations to determine their size, surface charge, morphology, and phototoxic effect. Subsequently, curcumin nanoparticles were transformed into a dry powder for inhalation utilizing spray drying and their morphology, aerodynamic properties and compatibility with pulmonary surfactant were investigated. Formulating curcumin inhalable powder in the form of NiMps rather than single component (curcumin only) microparticles will offer several advantages. Initially NiMps are microparticles with desirable aerodynamic properties facilitating a sufficient pulmonary deposition. Upon contact with lung fluids, they disintegrate into nanoparticles that are advantageous especially in terms of cellular internalization and evading macrophage uptake (Yang et al., 2008; Lebhardt et al., 2011; Muralidharan et al., 2015; Mangal
et al., 2017).

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text:
Poly(lactic‑co‑glycolic acid) (Resomer® RG 503H, molecular weight 29,000 g/mol, lactide:glycolide 50:50) was supplied by Evonik Nutrition & Care GmbH (Essen, Germany). Poly(vinyl alcohol) (Mowiol® 4-88) was a kind gift from Kuraray Europe GmbH (Frankfurt, Germany). Curcumin (≥80%), D‑Mannitol (≥98%), Rhodamine B (for fluorescence), 3‑(4,5‑dimethylthiazol‑2‑yl)‑2,5‑diphenyltetrazolium bromide (MTT) and 4′,6‑diamidino‑2‑phenylindole (DAPI) were all obtained from Sigma-Aldrich Chemie GmbH (Taufkirchen, Germany). Alveofact® was generously provided as a gift from Lyomark Pharma GmbH (Oberhaching, Germany). Sodium chloride (> 99.8%) was ordered from Carl Roth GmbH (Karlsruhe, Germany), Potassium chloride (≥99.5%), di-Sodium hydrogen phosphate dihydrate (≥99%) and potassium dihydrogen phosphate (≥99.5%) were all supplied by Merck KGaA (Darmstadt, Germany).
All solvents were of analytical or HPLC grade and were used as received. Ultra-pure water from PURELAB® flex 4 equipped with a Point-of-Use biofilter (ELGA LabWater, United Kingdom) was used for all experiments.

sections.heading: 2.2. Cell culture
sections.text: Human lung epithelial carcinoma cells (A549) were purchased from American Type Culture Collection (ATCC, Manassas, USA). The cells were cultured in DMEM medium (Capricorn Scientific, Ebsdorfergrund, Germany) supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (Sigma-Aldrich Chemie GmbH) and maintained at 37 °C and 5% CO2 under humid conditions. The cells were cultivated in monolayers and passaged upon reaching 80% confluency.

sections.heading: 2.3. Preparation of nanoparticles
sections.text: Curcumin loaded PLGA nanoparticles (PLGA.CUR.NPs) were prepared according to the nanoprecipitation method with slight modifications (Yallapu et al., 2010). Briefly, 200mg PLGA and 5mg curcumin were dissolved in 10ml acetone (organic phase). A beaker filled with a 40ml of 0.5% PVA solution (aqueous phase) was placed on a magnetic stirrer (IKA RT 15, IKA Werke, Staufen, Germany) at medium stirring speed (400 rpm). The organic phase was injected into the aqueous phase and the mixture was left stirring under light-protected conditions until complete evaporation of acetone. Afterwards, the final volume was adjusted to 50ml using water and the nanoparticles were stored at 4 °C until further characterization. Unloaded nanoparticles (PLGA.NPs) were also prepared following the same procedure except that the organic phase consisted only of PLGA.

sections.heading: 2.4. Encapsulation efficiency (EE)
sections.text:
Freshly prepared nanoparticles were centrifuged at 2000 g for 2min (Centrifuge 5418, Eppendorf AG, Hamburg, Germany) to determine the amount of free curcumin. The supernatant was carefully collected and the resulting pellet which contained the large free curcumin crystals was completely dissolved in ethanol. The amount of free curcumin was then quantified using a microplate spectrophotometer (Multiskan® GO, Thermo Scientific, Waltham, MA, USA) by measuring the absorbance at λ=420 nm.
EE% was calculated according to the following Eq. (1):

sections.heading: 2.5. Particle size distribution and ζ-potential
sections.text: Dynamic light scattering (DLS) and laser Doppler velocimetry (LDV) were performed using Zetasizer Nano ZS (Malvern Panalytical GmbH, Herrenberg, Germany) to determine the particle size and ζ-potential, respectively. The samples were diluted 1:100 with Phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) buffer (pH 7.4) and then placed in a clear disposable folded capillary cell (DTS1060, Malvern Panalytical GmbH). Prior to measurements, temperature of the samples was equilibrated to 25 °C. This instrument is equipped with Non-Invasive BackScatter (NIBS) technology that uses a detection angle of 173°. Measurement duration and number of sub-runs were automatically adjusted by the instrument (Al Meslmani et al., 2018).

sections.heading: 2.6. Scanning electron microscopy
sections.text: The morphology and particle size of the nanoparticles were investigated using scanning electron microscopy (SEM). The sample was pipetted onto a silica wafer and left to dry. Afterwards, the sample was sputter coated with a gold layer of ~15 nm at a current of 20mA for 50 s (Q150R ES, Quorum Technologies Ltd, East Grinstead, UK). The sample holder was then placed in the SEM (EVO HD15, Carl Zeiss Microscopy GmbH, Jena, Germany) and images were taken with an acceleration voltage of 5 kV and a secondary electron detector. Particle size analysis of the SEM micrographs was performed by measuring the diameter of a representative number of particles (n=250) using ImageJ software (version 1.47, National Institutes of Health, USA).

sections.heading: 2.7. In vitro cytotoxicity and irradiation experiments
sections.text: A prototype low power LED device (Lumundus GmbH, Eisenach, Germany) was used as light source to irradiate the cells. The device has been described elsewhere (Duse et al., 2018a). A549 cells were seeded onto 96-well plates (Nunclon Delta, Thermo Fischer Scientific GmbH, Dreieich, Germany) at a seeding density of 10,000 cells/0.35 cm2 (per well). After 24 h, the cells were incubated for 4 h with several concentrations of PLGA.CUR.NPs (i.e. 1.56–100 μM of curcumin) and equivalent volumes of PLGA.NPs. Subsequently, the samples were removed, and fresh medium was added. The cells were irradiated at λ=457 nm with different radiation fluence levels (i.e. 33.03 and 66.06 J/cm2) and were incubated overnight for 24 h. Unirradiated microtiter plate (dark) and untreated cells (blank) were used as controls. After the incubation time, the medium was removed, and the cells were incubated for 4 h with fresh medium containing dissolved MTT (1:10, 0.2 mg/ml). The remaining medium was then aspirated and 200 μl of dimethyl sulfoxide was added to each well to dissolve the resulting formazan crystals. The absorbance was measured at λ=570 nm (FLUOstar® OPTIMA). Viability of blank cells was considered as 100%.

sections.heading: 2.8. Visualization with confocal laser scanning microscope
sections.text:
For the visualization experiments, 90,000 cells/3.5 cm2 (per well) were seeded onto 12-well plates (Nunclon Delta, Thermo Fischer Scientific GmbH) containing cover slips (Ø 15mm). After 24 h, the cells were incubated with PLGA.CUR.NPs containing 100 μM curcumin or an equivalent volume of PLGA.NPs. After 4 h, the supernatant was removed and replaced with fresh medium and the plates were irradiated at a radiation fluence of 33.03 J/cm2. Unirradiated cells (dark) were used as a control. The cells were then washed with PBS containing Ca2+ and Mg2+ (pH 7.4) and fixed with 4% formaldehyde solution for 20min.
For counterstaining the cell nucleus, the cells were incubated with DAPI (0.1 μg/ml) for 20min. Finally, the cells were washed with PBS (pH 7.4) and the cover slips were mounted onto glass slides and sealed using FluorSave™ (Calbiochem Corp, La Jolla, USA). Subsequently, the cellular uptake of the nanoparticles and their photoresponse were visualized using confocal laser scanning microscope (CLSM) (Zeiss Axio Observer Z1 equipped with an LSM 700 confocal unit, Carl Zeiss Microscopy GmbH). All micrographs were recorded with a similar detector gain and pinhole size.

sections.heading: 2.9. Preparation of Nano-in-Microparticles
sections.text:
The nanoparticles were centrifuged at 13,000 rpm (20,064 g) for 60min at 4 °C (Sorvall RC6 Plus™ Superspeed Centrifuge, Rotor F218x50y, Thermo Scientific, Waltham, MA, USA). The supernatant was carefully collected, and the pellet was redispersed with the aid of vortexing and sonication in a solution of mannitol (matrix substance) and rhodamine B (0.1 wt% of mannitol) with a mass ratio of 30:70 (Nanoparticles:Matrix) and the solid concentration was adjusted to 1% (w/v) with water. Nano-in-Microparticles (NiMps) were prepared by spray drying the mixture of nanoparticles and mannitol using mini spray
dryer B-290 (BÜCHI Labortechnik AG, Flawil, Switzerland) equipped with two-fluid nozzle as previously described (Lebhardt et al., 2011). The process parameters were set as follows: inlet temperature 65 °C, aspirator 100%, pump rate 7%, spray gas flow 536 l/h, nozzle cleaner 1, outlet temperature≤ 41 °C. The spray dried product was collected with high performance cyclone and the yield% was calculated according to the following Eq. (2):
=Yield% Amount of the collected spray dried product (mg) Total amount of constituents used for preparation (mg) 100
(2)

sections.heading: 2.10. Redispersibility
sections.text: NiMps should be readily dispersible in aqueous media and disintegrate into the original nanoparticles. Therefore, a specific amount of the spray dried powder was weighed and redispersed in water with a final concentration of 1mg/ml. The sample was vortexed for 30 s and then placed in an ultrasound bath for 60 s at room temperature. Subsequently, particle size distribution of the redispersed sample was investigated using DLS (Ruge et al., 2016).

sections.heading: 2.11. Correlative light and electron microscopy
sections.text:
Correlative light and electron microscopy (CLEM) is a microscopy technique, based on the combination of electron and light microscopy. The Shuttle & Find setup (Carl Zeiss Microscopy GmbH) offers a modular system of standardized hardware and software for a straightforward relocation of any region of interest (ROI), both in the CLSM (LSM 710 NLO, Carl Zeiss Microscopy GmbH) and SEM (EVO HD15, Carl Zeiss Microscopy GmbH). The general procedure was described earlier (Tscheka et al., 2015). Due to the calibration of the Shuttle & Find specimen holder, each image was saved with its coordinates allowing relocating the reference point. No additional manipulation of the sample was necessary. The light microscopy was performed first, owing to possible inferences between the electron beam and the fluorophores (Smith, 2012). The microparticles were placed on a high precision coverslip (22× 22mm, 0.17mm thickness) and loose particles were removed with a stream of air. For the electron microscope, the sample was then sputter coated with a gold layer of ~30 nm using a current of 20mA for 100 s (Q150R ES, Quorum Technologies Ltd). Images were taken with an acceleration voltage of 5 kV and a secondary electron detector. The “Shuttle and Find” function in the ZEN 2 (blue edition)
software combines both microscope images together into one overlaying image.

sections.heading: 2.12. Aerodynamic properties
sections.text: A next generation impactor (NGI) (Copley Scientific AG, Therwil, Switzerland) was used to determine the aerodynamic properties of NiMps. Polyethylene capsule (size 3) was filled with approximately 20mg of the spray dried powder. Handihaler® (Boehringer Ingelheim, Ingelheim, Germany) was used as dry powder inhaler. All NGI cups were coated with an anti-bouncing agent (40% Brij® 35 (15% ethanolic solution) and 60% glycerol). Prior to experiment, the air flow rate was adjusted using flow meter (DFM 2000, Copley Scientific AG), critical flow controller (TPK, Copley Scientific AG) and high capacity pump (HCP5, Copley Scientific AG). To perform the test, one filled capsule was placed in the Handihaler® then punctured. The pump was then turned on and the powder was aerosolized at a flow rate of 60 l/min for 4 s. Afterwards, water was used to rinse the induction port, pre-separator, and the cups of the impactor. To calculate mass median aerodynamic diameter (MMAD), geometric standard deviation (GSD) and fine particle fraction (FPF), the amount of particles in each stages was quantified by measuring the fluorescence at λex= 540 nm and λem= 610 nm using a plate reader (FLUOstar® OPTIMA) (Torge et al., 2017).

sections.heading: 2.13. Langmuir film balance
sections.text:
Langmuir film balance was utilized as in vitro model to investigate the biophysical properties of pulmonary surfactant upon contact with the nanoparticles. Using the naturally-derived pulmonary surfactant; Alveofact®, alveoli specific surface pressures could be generated. The surface pressure (π) is the difference between the surface tension of pure water (γ0) and the measured surface tension (γ) (Eq. (3)).
= 0 (3)
Surface pressure measurements in the film balance (Riegler & Kirstein GmbH, Potsdam, Germany; Teflon trough 100ml total volume and total area of 171 cm2) were performed according to Wilhelmymethod (Bakowsky et al., 2000). Alveofact® was dissolved in cyclohexane to a final concentration of 1mg/ml. PBS (pH 7.4, filtered through 0.2 μm syringe filter) was used as the subphase (i.e. the aqueous medium on which the monolayer will spread). All experiments were performed at 25 °C. Five minutes after spreading Alveofact® on the surface, the monolayer was formed. The monolayer was compressed, and the total surface area was reduced to generate two different surface pressures (i.e. 25 mN/m and 42mN/m). Afterwards, the monolayer was left to stabilize for 15min. The redispersed nanoparticles were then injected under the monolayer into the subphase (Fig. 1). The π-t (pressure-time) isotherms were recorded by a control unit (Riegler & Kirstein).
The utilization of two-dimensional lipid model membranes is a welldocumented and frequently used approach for characterizing drugmembrane interactions. In order to obtain comparable results to those of 3D systems (e.g. differential scanning calorimetry), the ideal gas law i.e. PV=nRT or PA=nRT (in case of 2D systems, where: P is the lateral film pressure, and A is the molecular area) is used to adjust the parameters. In monolayer systems, only temperatures which are slightly above room temperature can reasonably be produced, the lateral
pressure (P) and the molecular area (A) were adjusted to be equivalent to those of a temperature of 37 °C. This ensures that the same fluidity and identical diffusion coefficients can be achieved as in case of 3D system with a temperature of 37 °C.
In this regard, it is worth mentioning that an experimental setup where the particles are aerosolized on the film balance would describe the situation in the lungs more correctly. However, due to the fact that spraying on the conventional film balance would be problematic, especially in terms of monolayer stability, there is still no validated technique available with such a setup.

sections.heading: 2.14. Statistical analysis
sections.text: All measurements were performed in triplicates and the values are presented as mean ± standard deviation, unless otherwise stated. Two-tailed Student's t-test was performed to identify statistical significance differences. Probability values of p < 0.05 were considered significant.

sections.heading: 3.1. Physicochemical properties of the nanoparticles
sections.text:
A nanoprecipitation method was used to produce curcumin loaded nanoparticles, which is a well-established method for preparing PLGA nanoparticles with a narrow size distribution and controllable particle size (Rao and Geckeler, 2011). PLGA is approved by FDA and EMA for drug delivery applications with several products in the market. Moreover, PLGA has been proven to be safe for pulmonary drug delivery according to several in vitro and in vivo studies (Danhier et al., 2012; Ungaro et al., 2012; Martins et al., 2018). To the best of our knowledge, there is still no PLGA-based approved products for pulmonary applications with no reports about clinical trials in this regard.
Preliminary experiments were performed to improve the preparation method by optimizing the parameters which had significant effect on particle size, dispersity, and encapsulation efficiency (e.g. concentration of PLGA, concentration of PVA and curcumin loading). DLS and LDV measurements did not indicate any significant effect of curcumin encapsulation on particle size, polydispersity index (PdI) or ζpotential (p > 0.05). Both unloaded and loaded nanoparticles had a similar hydrodynamic diameter with monodisperse size distribution (PdI≤ 0.1) and a negative surface charge (Table 1).
PLGA nanoparticles have been previously reported to have the ability to efficiently encapsulate curcumin (Yallapu et al., 2010). Spectrophotometric quantification revealed that 2.5% loading of curcumin (%wt of the polymer) is the most appropriate concentration leading to a relatively high encapsulation efficiency (Table 1). Moreover, when higher curcumin concentrations were used (≥5%), a yellowish-orange ring appeared on the inside of the beaker. The width of the formed ring increased proportionately with increasing the concentration of curcumin due to higher amounts of free curcumin that were precipitating on the beaker while evaporating the solvent.
SEM micrographs of PLGA.CUR.NPs showed that the nanoparticles were spherical and had a homogenous size distribution with few larger particles which were not detected with DLS (Fig. 2A). Average particle size was around 160 nm which is slightly smaller than the size obtained from DLS measurements. This difference in particle size can be attributed to sample preparation and measurement principle since DLS measurements were performed while the nanoparticles were still suspended in a dispersant (e.g. water or buffer), whereas in case of SEM, the samples were left to dry first (Gaumet et al., 2008).

sections.heading: 3.2. Photodynamic activity
sections.text:
The successful application of curcumin nanoformulations against cancer is well documented (Naksuriya et al., 2014). Moreover, theFig. 1. Schematic diagram illustrating the Langmuir monolayer experiment.
combination of curcumin and PDT is a well-proven strategy offering higher selectivity towards tumor cells and more localized treatment omitting the need of higher doses or longer incubation times (Duse et al., 2018a; Duse et al., 2018b). In this study, the photoactivity of the nanoparticles was evaluated by measuring their ability to destroy cancer cells upon exposure to light of a specific wavelength. As seen in Fig. 3, the nanoparticles exhibited minimal cytotoxicity when the cells were not irradiated (dark). Upon irradiation using an LED device, a significant decrease in the cellular viability was observed for both radiation fluence levels. The nanoparticles showed a dose-dependent photocytotoxicity and the effective response was noticed above certain curcumin dose (> 12.5 μM). The half-maximal inhibitory concentration (IC50) for curcumin was calculated from the fitted dose-response curves and was found to be 27.38 μM for 33.03 J/cm2 and 17.14 μM for 66.06 J/cm2. Unloaded nanoparticles were used as a control and did not exhibit any significant photocytotoxicity regardless of the dose or the radiation fluence (data not shown). A key factor for an effective PDT is the sufficient cellular uptake of the photosensitizer by the target tumor cells (Mahmoud et al., 2017; Robertson et al., 2009). Therefore, CLSM was used to visualize the intracellular localization of curcumin after incubating the nanoparticles with A549 cells for 4 h. High fluorescence intensity was observed confirming the successful uptake of PLGA.CUR.NPs with curcumin mostly localized near the cell nucleus

(Fig. 4B). Upon irradiation, more intensive and distributed fluorescence was observed (Fig. 4D) in comparison with unirradiated cells indicating further release of curcumin from the nanoparticles (Duse et al., 2018b).

sections.heading: 3.3. Physicochemical properties of the Nano-in-Microparticles
sections.text:
NiMps were produced by spray drying PLGA.CUR.NPs mixed with a solution of polyol matrix (mannitol). The spray drying parameters were optimized to achieve high powder yield and enhanced aerodynamic properties, taking into consideration the physical properties of PLGA, especially the glass transition temperature (46.34 °C). After collecting the spray dried product, yield% was calculated and found to be 54.80 ± 4.21%. This is considered a very good product yield which can be related to the use of high-performance cyclone which facilitated the recovery of a high amount of the spray dried product (Amaro et al., 2011). Mannitol was chosen as matrix excipient due to its suitability for pulmonary applications. It has already been used in several inhalable pharmaceutical products in the European Union and many countries worldwide, e.g. Aridol® and Bronchitol® (Pharmaxis Ltd, Sydney, Australia) (Rahimpour et al., 2014; Healy et al., 2014). Moreover, mannitol has a high aqueous solubility which is essential for the disintegration of the microparticles to release the nanoparticles once they are deposited in the lungs (Torge et al., 2017). Matrix excipients other than mannitol have been also used in the preparation of PLGA-based inhalable NiMps, e.g. lactose, trehalose and chitosan (El-Sherbiny and Smyth, 2012; Bohr et al., 2015). However, using polycationic polymers like chitosan as a matrix substance will lead to electrostatic interactions with the anionic lipids in the lung surfactant and critically influencing their surface activity (Zuo et al., 2008; Kang et al., 2008).
Redispersibility of NiMps was evaluated by redispersing the sprayed powder in water. DLS measurements of the redispersed nanoparticles
revealed a particle size of 233.41 ± 24.22 nm and PdI of 0.23 ± 0.03. This increase in particle size and PdI could be due to slight aggregation caused by shear forces during the atomization step. Similar findings were observed by Lebhardt et al. as they measured the size of the PLGA nanoparticles collected directly after atomization (without heating) and reported a size increase of approximately 9%. An increase in the PDI values was also noticed (Lebhardt et al., 2011). However, several parameters must still be investigated in order to better understand the reason behind the size increase of the redispersed nanoparticles after spray drying. A very crucial parameter indeed is the amount of mechanical force (e.g. vortexing or sonication) that is required to sufficiently redisperse the centrifuged nanoparticles in the solution of the matrix excipient. Other factors should also be studied, e.g. type of matrix excipient, Nanoparticles:Matrix mass ratio and the spray drying parameters, especially feed rate and spray air flow.
Even after storage for almost five months, NiMps were readily dispersible confirming the benefit of spray drying in improving long-term stability of the nanoparticles. Furthermore, mannitol plays a vital role in increasing the space between the nanoparticles which will reduce particle-particle interactions and improve the disintegration of the microparticles (Wang et al., 2017).
SEM micrographs of NiMps (Fig. 2B and C) showed raisin-like particles with wrinkled morphology and relatively broad particle size distribution ranging from 0.5 to 4 μm.
Similar morphological findings were previously reported by Torge et al. where the influence of nanoparticle-to-mannitol ratio on the morphology of PLGA-based NiMps was investigated. The study reported testing several Nanoparticles:Matrix ratios ranging from 0% to 100% nanoparticle percentage. According to the findings of the study, only pure mannitol particles had a spherical shape, whereas the incorporation of nanoparticles at all ratios led to the formation of less spherical
and more collapsed particles (Torge et al., 2017). Additional details about NiMps structure were obtained from CLEM imaging which served as a confirmation of the nanoparticle distribution within the microparticles (Fig. 2D). Moreover, using CLSM, it was also possible to confirm the ability of mannitol to embed nanoparticles homogenously by analyzing each fluorescence channel separately since the nanoparticles were loaded with curcumin and mannitol was labeled with Rhodamine B (Fig. 5). Previous studies reported similar results with mannitol and different types of nanoparticles (Grenha et al., 2007; Torge et al., 2017).

sections.heading: 3.4. Aerodynamic properties and lung compatibility
sections.text:
The pulmonary deposition of inhaled particles is significantly controlled by their aerodynamic properties. An aerodynamic diameter between 1 and 5 μm will help achieving higher particle deposition in the lung especially in the lower airways (Bohr et al., 2014). NiMps were characterized using NGI which is one of the devices recommended by the European Pharmacopoeia for aerodynamic assessment of fine particles. NiMps exhibited good aerosolization behavior with MMAD of 3.02 ± 0.07 μm within the desirable range and high FPF (64.94 ± 3.47%). GSD was found to be 1.74 ± 0.16 indicating a polydisperse powder which was also noticed in SEM micrographs. This GSD value, however, falls within the typical range for most pharmaceutical aerosols (i.e. 1.5–2.5) (Newman et al., 2009). NGI results proved the ability of NiMps to deliver the nanoparticles efficiently to the lungs omitting the need of additional excipients like coarse carrier particles (e.g. lactose) or aerosolization enhancer (e.g. amino acids). Following deposition NiMps will come in contact with lung fluids. Depending on their deposition site, the particles have to pass the mucus blanket within the airways or pulmonary surfactant layer lining the alveolar epithelium to reach their target (Yang et al., 2008). In this regard, the interaction of NiMps with a monolayer of bovine lung surfactant (Alveofact®) was investigated using Langmuir film balance. Two different surface pressures were used to simulate the interaction of the redispersed nanoparticles with pulmonary surfactant during the breathing process (Wüstneck et al., 2005). The pure monolayers were in continuous phase at those pressures. Fig. 6 shows the π-t isotherm of pure Alveofact® dynamically compressed up to a surface pressure of 25mN/m (A) and 42mN/m (B) at a velocity of 20 cm2/min. After reaching the desired surface pressure, the barriers were stopped so that the Alveofact® monolayer could equilibrate. The properties of the Alveofact® monolayer were then monitored for 60min. Directly after the barriers stopped, the π-t isotherms of pure Alveofact® decreased by 1–2mN/m. This was caused by a new array of lipids in the monolayer after the dynamic compression or due to other processes like relaxation
and desorption (Rodríguez Niño et al., 2008). Subsequently, the monolayer equilibrated and the surface pressures stabilized. The gray curves represent the π-t isotherms where 20 μl of the redispersed nanoparticles were added 15min after the barriers were stopped. After the injection of the nanoparticles, no change in the π-t isotherm could be observed at both tested surface pressures, suggesting no substantial interaction between the nanoparticles and surfactant. In other words, integration of the nanoparticles into the surfactant monolayer would have caused an increase in the surface pressure over time, and vice versa, a decrease in the surface pressure would mean that the nanoparticles have either withdrawn the compounds out of the monolayer or destroyed it (Bakowsky et al., 2000). These outcomes confirmed that NiMps with all its components (nanoparticles and mannitol) are compatible with pulmonary surfactant at physiological pressures.
The fate of PLGA nanoparticles and their elimination rate are very important points that still need to be addressed. There are numerous possibilities, e.g. degradation, macrophage uptake and clearance, or exhalation. However, it is difficult to exactly tell which one is dominant in our case due to the lack of details in the scientific literature in this regard. The only available reports are based either on ex vivo lung models or in vivo studies and in all cases PLGA nanoparticles were administered as nanoparticle suspension (by means of nebulization for example) rather than in the form of Nano-in-Microparticles as a dry powder for inhalation. However, in order to better understand the fate and the pharmacokinetics of PLGA nanoparticles, there is still an urgent need for in vivo studies wherein Nano-in-Microparticles are administered via the pulmonary route as a dry powder for inhalation.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
In the present work, spray drying was employed to transform curcumin loaded nanoparticles into a more stable dry powder for inhalation without experiencing drastic conditions. Mannitol was used as the wall material embedding the nanoparticles to keep them intact during the drying process and facilitate their release from the microparticles. The produced Nano-in-Microparticles offer double benefit; nanoparticles efficiently encapsulating curcumin to enhance its therapeutic efficacy and microparticles serving as an intermediate carrier with suitable aerodynamic properties for sufficient deposition in the lung. Furthermore, the good compatibility of the Nano-in-Microparticles with pulmonary surfactant is an important prerequisite for the safe delivery of curcumin to its site of action in the lungs (i.e. tumor cells). The outcomes of this study confirmed the feasibility of preparing an inhalable curcumin formulation that can be applied in combination with bronchoscopic photodynamic therapy. This will help achieving both selective and completely non-invasive treatment against lung cancer.
Thus, offering a promising alternative to the intravenous route and improving patient compliance.

metadata.abstractText: Photodynamic therapy is amongst the most rapidly developing therapeutic strategies against cancer. However, most photosensitizers are administered intravenously with very few reports about pulmonary applications. To address this issue, an inhalable formulation consisting of nanoparticles loaded with photosensitizer (i.e. curcumin) was developed. The nanoparticles were prepared using nanoprecipitation method. Dynamic light scattering measurements of the curcumin loaded nanoparticles revealed a hydrodynamic diameter of 181.20 ± 11.52 nm. In vitro irradiation experiments with human lung epithelial carcinoma cells (A549) showed a selective cellular toxicity of the nanoparticles upon activation using LED irradiating device. Moreover, curcumin nanoparticles exhibited a dose-dependent photocytotoxicity and the IC50 values of curcumin were directly dependent on the radiation fluence used. The nanoparticles were subsequently spray dried using mannitol as a stabilizer to produce Nano-in-Microparticles with appropriate aerodynamic properties for a sufficient deposition in the lungs. This was confirmed using the next generation impactor, which revealed a large fine particle fraction (64.94 ± 3.47%) and a mass median aerodynamic diameter of 3.02 ± 0.07 μm. Nano-in-Microparticles exhibited a good redispersibility and disintegrated into the original nanoparticles upon redispersion in aqueous medium. The Langmuir monolayer experiments revealed an excellent compatibility of the nanoparticles with the lung surfactant. Results from this study showed that the Nano-in-Microparticles are promising drug carriers for the photodynamic therapy of lung cancer.
